bestBHT.bht: Resuming from the interrupted discourse, this describes her flight into the wilderness due to deadly persecution. The rise of the papacy and persecutions under it posed a determined and deadly opposition to spiritual religion. The dragon attacks the church by stirring up earthly-minded Christians and barbarous nations against her. Christian emperors showed more regard for Paganism than orthodox religion, and the dragon turned his wrath to cause all possible mischief on earth.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Resuming from the thread of the discourse, which had been interrupted by the episode, this verse accounts for her flight into the wilderness.
Albert Barnes: When Satan saw that he was doomed to discomfiture and overthrow...he 'persecuted the woman'."
The child is represented as safe; that is, the ultimate progress and extension of the church was certain."

It is unnecessary to say that, after the pagan persecutions ceased...his enmity was vented in another form - in the rise of the papacy, and in the persecutions under that an opposition to spiritual religion no less determined and deadly than what had been waged by paganism.
Archibald T. Robertson: The child was caught away...deadly persecution."
Perhaps events since A.D. 64...still do so.
John Gill: he attacks the woman, the church, in a new way, by stirring up earthly minded professors of Christianity, the Arians, against her, and by bringing in an inundation of the barbarous nations into the empire, now become Christian
these were Christian emperors in name, but they exercised all the cruelties of the Heathen ones, if they did not exceed them; and a greater regard was shown to Paganism than to the orthodox religion

Valens tolerated all religions but that, especially Heathenism; all his reign the fire burned upon the altars, images were honoured with libations and sacrifices, the public festivals of the Heathens were kept, and the rites of Bacchus were performed in the streets
John Wesley: And when the dragon saw — That be could no longer accuse the saints in heaven, he turned his wrath to do all possible mischief on earth."

He persecuted the woman — The ancient persecutions of the church were mentioned, Revelation 1:9; 2:10; 7:14; but this persecution came after her flight, verse6, Revelation 12:6 just at the beginning of the third woe."
These, and all the accounts of those times, show with what fury the dragon then persecuted the woman.

bhtAttempts.bht: Resuming from the thread of the discourse, which had been interrupted by the episode, this verse accounts for her flight into the wilderness. The child was caught away, facing deadly persecution. After pagan persecutions ceased, the rise of the papacy and persecutions under that posed a no less determined and deadly opposition to spiritual religion. In a new way, the dragon attacks the church by stirring up earthly-minded Christians against her and bringing in barbarous nations into the Christian empire. These Christian emperors showed more regard for Paganism than for the orthodox religion, and the dragon turned his wrath to cause all possible mischief on earth.

Resuming from the thread of the discourse, which had been interrupted by the episode, this verse accounts for her flight into the wilderness in the face of deadly persecution. After pagan persecutions ceased, the rise of the papacy and persecutions under that posed a no less determined and deadly opposition to spiritual religion. In a new way, the dragon attacks the church by stirring up earthly-minded Christians against her and bringing in barbarous nations into the Christian empire. These Christian emperors showed more regard for Paganism than for the orthodox religion, and the dragon turned his wrath to cause all possible mischief on earth.

This verse continues the narrative by explaining the reason for her flight into the wilderness, where she would find refuge from the relentless persecution she faced. The rise of the papacy brought forth a new wave of hostility towards the church, with the persecutions under it proving to be just as determined and deadly as the earlier pagan persecutions. The dragon, in his relentless pursuit, not only stirred up earthly-minded Christians against her but also brought in barbarous nations to intensify the opposition against the church.

This reveals the reason for her flight into the wilderness, seeking refuge from the hostile pursuit and deadly persecution she experienced. The rise of the papacy introduced a different form of opposition to the church, unleashing persecutions as determined and deadly as those under paganism. The dragon continued his attack, inciting earthly-minded Christians and barbarous nations against the church. These new persecutions showed a disregard for orthodox religion, as Christian emperors allowed Paganism to thrive while targeting the church.
